passages.title: Passage I
passages.text:
The African moralist has always regarded smoking as an indication of moral degradation.

A number of people have accepted the moralist idea on smoking while a good many people have remained indifferent to the moralist view and have continued to smoke. The same argument has been applied to the consumption of alcohol. The African moralist, basing his judgement on the behaviour of a few alcoholics, tend to regard the habit of taking alcohol as a sign of wretchedness. The moralist holds the view that anybody who forms the habit of consuming alcohol will never do well in life. While this may be true in respect of a few people in the society, the fear of the moralist has not been justified.

However, the economist is primarily interested in the habit of smoking and the consumption of alcohol in so far as they give satisfaction to smokers and drinkers and so generate supply of and demand for tobacco and alcohol.

Some moral principles associated with religion tend to lead on to economic problems. Followers of certain religions are expected not to consume pork, take alcohol or smoke tobacco. Devotees of some religious groups, on the other hand, can eat pork while others are expected to abstain from alcohol and smoking.

Strict observance of these moral rules could cripple the breweries, the cigarette factories and some businesses; however, there seems to be a growing number of alcohol consumers and cigarette smokers—a development which should be of interest to the economist.

Adapted from Peter Scott's article in Sunday Times.

passages.title: Passage II
passages.text:
When man evolved a conscience, his basic relationship with the other animals began to change. Until then, they were broadly divided into those which ate him when they got the chance, those which he ate when he got the chance, and a third group which competed with him for food, or was otherwise a nuisance to him in the business of keeping alive.

In the primitive situation, man was, therefore, basically against nature but, as the battle was progressively won, conscience crept in; the awareness of responsibility, and a failure to meet it, produced feelings of guilt.

Those who live in cities and need no longer do battle against nature are nowadays most actively for nature. At this time, something like a thousand kinds of animals (vertebrate animals) can be said to be in danger of extinction. A few of them have been reduced to this precarious position by extensive killing but the majority are disappearing only as fast as the particular kind of country they need for existence is itself disappearing and all the hands of man, as often as not by mistake.

There are three species of turtles whose future survival is menaced by the demand for turtle soup, which would hardly justify the extermination of a giant reptile whose family has existed for 200 million years.

Leopards are in jeopardy because of the fashion for their skins. As they get rarer, the prices rise and, as leopard skin become more expensive, the demand increases. No species can long survive the price of N60,000 which a half-grown baby leopard now carries on its skin.

And crocodiles, the longest surviving reptiles, are now dwindling alarmingly as a result of the fashion in crocodile skin for ladies' handbags and men's shoes. The human population explosion spreads mankind across the land surfaces of the earth at an alarming rate. There will be twice as many of us before most of us are dead. Does this mean no room for wild animals? Of course not.

Adapted from Peter Scott's article in Sunday Times.

passages.title: Passage III
passages.text: A prepared speech is not easy to deliver, especially if it is not written by the presenter. ....11.... delivery is one in which the speech has been written out word for word and is read to ....12.... . This type of delivery is usually reserved for very ....13.... occasions when exact wording is ....14.... such as the State of the Union Address or speeches before the United Nations General ....15.... . The primary advantage is that the speech may be highly ....16.... in terms of word choice, turns of phrase and development of ideas. Reading aloud with meaningful ....17.... inflection requires the speaker to be very familiar with the text. If not, the words will come out in a choppy, expressionless way. Such poor delivery could ....18.... effects created by the carefully chosen ....19.... . Lack of familiarity with the ....20.... could also prevent the speaker from maintaining eye contact with the people being addressed.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 20, answer the questions based on the passages.
In each of questions 21 to 36, answer the questions based on A.H. Mohammed’s "The Last Day at Forcados High School".
In each of questions 37 to 45, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
In each of questions 46 to 50, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 51 to 56, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 57 to 64, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 65 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap(s).
In each of questions 86 to 89, choose the option that has the same vowel sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
In each of questions 90 to 91, choose the option that has the same consonant sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
In each of questions 92 to 94, choose the option that rhymes with the given word.
In each of questions 95 to 97, choose the most appropriate stress pattern from the options. The stressed syllables are written in capital letters.
In each of questions 98 to 100, the word in capital letters has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence is the appropriate reply.

questions.question: The view expressed by the writer in the last paragraph is that

options.text: the number of alcoholics and smokers is certainly increasing
more people appear to take to drinking and smoking
sales of alcohol and tobacco products have improved tremendously
more people now abstain from drinking and smoking

questions.explanation: In the last paragraph of Passage I the writer notes that "there seems to be a growing number of alcohol consumers and cigarette smokers". That means more people are **taking to** drinking and smoking. The passage says nothing about sales figures (C), the number of alcoholics specifically (A), or increased abstinence (D).

questions.question: It can be concluded from the passage that morality, religion and economy are
questions.explanation: Moral and religious rules against smoking, alcohol and pork can "cripple" breweries and cigarette factories—an **economic** effect. At the same time, economists look at smoking and drinking in terms of satisfaction, supply and demand. So there is a connection, but not a simple or absolute one; morality and religion do not fully control the economy. "Somewhat interconnected" (A) is therefore more accurate than "clearly interconnected" (B) or "certainly unrelated" (D).

questions.question: According to the passage, the moralist idea is that

options.text: the smoking of cigarettes is bad and unacceptable
it is typically African not to smoke cigarettes
people should accept a point of view only when they are convinced
smoking is not good but a little alcohol may be permitted

questions.explanation: The first sentence states that the African moralist "has always regarded smoking as an indication of moral degradation". That directly means smoking is seen as morally bad and unacceptable. The passage does not say that non‑smoking is specially African (B), nothing about when people should accept views (C), and in fact the moralist condemns alcohol as well, so D is false.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true according to the passage?

options.text: total abstinence from drinking and smoking is a religious obligation
smoking and drinking may have positive effects on the economy
everyone ignores the moralist view on drinking and smoking
people who drink or smoke surely die of cancer

questions.explanation: The economist, the passage says, is interested in smoking and drinking "in so far as they give satisfaction" and "generate supply of and demand for tobacco and alcohol". Generating supply and demand is an economic positive. Option A exaggerates—some religions restrict these habits, others do not. C contradicts the text since "a number of people" accept the moralist idea. D introduces a medical claim (cancer) that is never mentioned.

questions.question: The positions maintained by the moralist and the economist can be described as being
questions.explanation: The moralist sees smoking and drinking as "moral degradation" and "wretchedness". The economist, by contrast, is interested in the **satisfaction** and economic activity they generate. These viewpoints are fundamentally opposed, not "agreeable" (B) or indifferent (A). So the two positions are "at variance"—they clash.

questions.question: The sentence 'There will be twice as many of us before most of us are dead' means

options.text: some increase in human and animal population growth rates
mankind is fast spreading across the earth
the population will double before the present generation dies
many of us will die as a result of population explosion

questions.explanation: The statement is about numbers, not geography or causes of death. "Twice as many of us before most of us are dead" clearly projects that the human population will **double within the lifetime** of most people now living. A is too vague; B talks about spread across the earth; D introduces death from population explosion, which is not said.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true according to the passage?

options.text: man kills animals only when he can afford to do so
man eats all categories of animals
man cannot spare those animals that eat his kind
man poses the greatest threat to nature

questions.explanation: The author describes many animal species threatened by **human** activity: over‑killing for soup and skin fashions, and destruction of habitats by expanding human populations. He concludes that man's actions—often "by mistake"—push animals toward extinction. This makes man the greatest threat to nature (D). The passage never says A, B, or C.

questions.question: The basic causes of the elimination of certain animals from the earth include

options.text: a deliberate battle against nature and the quest for leopard skin
man's decision to live in cities and the development of large farm lands
man's penchant for meat and the sale of animals for meat and hides
extensive killing of animals and the fast disappearance of their favourable habitats

questions.explanation: Scott states that a **few** species are endangered by "extensive killing", but that "the majority are disappearing only as fast as the particular kind of country they need for existence is itself disappearing" under man's hand. This two‑part cause—killing plus habitat loss—is summarised in D. Options A–C capture pieces of the story but not the complete, explicit pair of causes the passage stresses.

questions.question: The expression 'when man evolved a conscience' means when

options.text: man developed an awareness of right and wrong

questions.explanation: Immediately after the phrase, the passage explains that "the awareness of responsibility, and a failure to meet it, produced feelings of guilt." Guilt over not meeting responsibility is precisely what a **moral conscience** is about: awareness of right and wrong and one's duty. This is more specific than merely improved intellect (A), critical thinking (B), or new habits (D).

questions.question: From the passage, the attitude of the writer can be described as
questions.explanation: The writer lists many species that are "in danger of extinction" or "dwindling alarmingly" because of human actions and warns of population explosion. He does not express hope that the situation will improve; instead he paints a bleak picture. This tone is "pessimistic". He is clearly not indifferent (A) and does not favour one side over another (B), nor does he sound hopeful (C).

questions.question: A prepared speech is not easy to deliver, especially if it is not written by the presenter. ....11.... delivery is one in which the speech has been written out word for word and is read to the audience.
questions.explanation: The gap describes a **type of delivery** in which a fully written text is read aloud. Such a delivery is called *manuscript delivery*, i.e. reading from a complete written script. 'Quantum' and 'free' do not describe speech types; 'document' is too general (it is a thing, not a delivery style).

questions.question: A prepared speech is not easy to deliver, especially if it is not written by the presenter. Manuscript delivery is one in which the speech has been written out word for word and is read to ....12....
questions.explanation: The general word for people listening to a speech is "audience". A congregation is specifically a religious audience, and a conference is the event itself rather than the listeners. 'Gathering' is very broad, but 'audience' is the standard term in public-speaking contexts.

questions.question: This kind of delivery is usually reserved for very ....13.... occasions when exact wording is critical.
questions.explanation: Examples given are the State of the Union Address and speeches before the United Nations General Assembly. These are highly **formal** occasions where wording must be precise. Impromptu (B) is the opposite of prepared; 'genuine' and 'guaranteed' do not describe the level of ceremony.

questions.question: This kind of delivery is usually reserved for very formal occasions when exact wording is ....14....
questions.explanation: In such ceremonial speeches, specific words are **critical**—they may have legal or diplomatic implications. 'Reportive' is not standard English; 'conclusive' refers to finality, not essential importance.

questions.question: This kind of delivery is usually reserved for very formal occasions when exact wording is critical, such as the State of the Union Address or speeches before the United Nations General ....15....
questions.explanation: The proper name is "United Nations General **Assembly**". 'Organisation' refers to the UN as a whole (United Nations Organisation), and 'negotiation' is an activity, not a body.

questions.question: The primary advantage is that the speech may be highly ....16.... in terms of word choice, turns of phrase and development of ideas.
questions.explanation: Because every word can be chosen and revised beforehand, a manuscript speech can be very **polished**—refined and well‑crafted. 'Advanced' is too vague; 'analogue' and 'discreet' do not relate to style or quality of wording.

questions.question: Reading aloud with meaningful ....17.... inflection requires the speaker to be very familiar with the text.
questions.explanation: "Inflection" here refers to variation in **voice** (pitch, tone, loudness). The appropriate adjective is "vocal". 'Bifocal' relates to glasses, 'anticipatory' to expectation, and 'profuse' to abundance, none of which modify 'inflection' properly.

questions.question: If not, the words will come out in a choppy, expressionless way. Such poor delivery could ....18.... effects created by the carefully chosen language.
questions.explanation: Poor delivery limits or undermines the effectiveness of the words, **restricting** the impact of the carefully chosen language. The other options describe desirable effects; they contradict the idea of "poor delivery".

questions.question: Such poor delivery could restrictive effects created by the carefully chosen ....19....
questions.explanation: The writer is talking about the choices of words and expressions in a speech. The natural phrase is "carefully chosen **language**". Dialect and slang are specific kinds of language, not the broad neutral term intended.

questions.question: Lack of familiarity with the ....20.... could also prevent the speaker from maintaining eye contact with the people being addressed.
questions.explanation: The issue is that the speaker must **read** the prepared words. If he does not know the **text** well, he must keep looking down at it and cannot easily maintain eye contact. 'Context' is background situation, which does not cause this problem; 'exchange' and 'note' are not accurate here.

questions: The Last Day at Forcados High School

questions.question: According to the novel, Efua was in Forcados High School because

options.text: her stepfather was a board member
the school needed her mother's support
of Aunt Muni's gift to the school

questions.explanation: Efua is admitted to Forcados largely because Aunt Muni makes a substantial donation to the school. This gift gives her influence with the principal, and Efua benefits from that. The text does not mention a board‑member stepfather (A), a former principal (B), or her mother's support (C) as the decisive reasons.

questions.question: According to the novel, who intimated Efua that there was a clash between area boys?
questions.explanation: Mr Mallum, the principal, warns Efua about the danger posed by area boys. As head of the school he is responsible for the students' safety, so it is natural that he is the one to intimate her about the clash.

questions.question: The speculation amongst the students of Forcados High School was that Jimi was dating
questions.explanation: Jimi and Efua are often seen together, and their closeness sparks rumours that they are dating. These rumours fuel tension between characters. There is no similar school‑wide speculation about the other girls listed.

questions.question: The best thing that happened to Efua at the end of the term was

options.text: her participation in the Christmas concert
her exclusion from Miss Novi's charity group
the principal's open commendation of her result

questions.explanation: Despite the prejudice she faces, Efua performs excellently in her studies. Mr Mallum’s public commendation of her result is a powerful recognition of her ability. For an academically serious and socially misunderstood girl, this open praise is the highlight of the term.

questions.question: When did a boy faint at Forcados High School?
questions.explanation: The fainting incident happens at the **mid‑term dinner**, an important social event in the novel. The author uses this scene to reveal character traits and tensions. It does not occur at the prize‑giving, valedictory service or inter‑house sports.

questions.question: Mr Mallum, the principal, was a symbol of
questions.explanation: Mr Mallum is portrayed as a disciplined, successful school head, an embodiment of academic and moral **achievement**. Students look up to him as someone who has risen to a respected position through hard work.

questions.question: Ansa decided not to like Efua because he
questions.explanation: Ansa initially misreads Efua’s quiet, reserved nature as **snobbishness**, thinking she feels superior to others. This mistaken impression colours his attitude toward her for some time.

questions.question: In the novel, Ansa looked around glumly when Jimi was engrossed in laughter and chatter because he was

options.text: distracted by a boy playing on the field
given twelve strokes of the cane by the principal

questions.explanation: Ansa feels left out and neglected when Jimi spends time joking and chatting with others, especially with Efua. His glumness comes from jealousy and a sense that his friend is drifting away.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best captures Ansa's thought about Jimi?

options.text: He thought Jimi was a lucky boy.
He was going to break his friendship with Jimi.
He thought Jimi cut corners to succeed.
He was envious of Jimi's achievement.

questions.explanation: Ansa is often resentful of Jimi’s talents and popularity. He feels overshadowed and is **envious** of Jimi’s academic success and social ease. The other options either understate or misrepresent this jealousy.

questions.question: Jimi was still trembling when he got home from the bar because

options.text: he ran into a team of policemen
Wole's friend wanted to beat him
he saw an accident on the way

questions.explanation: The frightening encounter with a team of policemen after the bar incident leaves Jimi shaken. The fear of arrest and its consequences explains why he keeps trembling even after reaching home. The other options do not match the narrative.

questions.question: After listening to Jimi's explanation on the stolen laboratory equipment, Mr Mallum decided to

options.text: get in touch with Jimi's relations
put an end to the matter
contact the police for Jimi's release

questions.explanation: Recognising Jimi’s remorse and perhaps the mitigating circumstances, Mr Mallum chooses not to escalate the issue. He decides to "put an end to the matter", effectively closing the case internally rather than involving more punishment or the police.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Mr Mallum?

options.text: He was a small, wiry man with odd accent.
He was a tall, wiry man with good diction.
He was crude, rash and impatient.
He was a fat, tall man with wimpyish behaviour.

questions.explanation: In the novel, Mr Mallum is described as a **tall, wiry** man who speaks clearly and firmly, reflecting "good diction". This matches option B; the other options contradict the physical and behavioural description given by the author.

questions.question: How did Nene feel when she saw Efua's painting by Ansa?
questions.explanation: Nene is struck by Ansa's painting of Efua; it reveals a side of both of them she had not fully appreciated. Her reaction is one of **surprise**, not necessarily instant delight or friendliness.

questions.question: One of the things Ansa observed about his fellow students when they resumed for the new term was that some of them

options.text: wore their ties in odd knots
were eager to go back home

questions.explanation: Ansa notices that some students return from the holiday "sickly and malnourished", suggesting they come from poor backgrounds. This detail underlines economic inequality among students. There is no notable mention of odd tie‑knots, eagerness to go home, or increased rudeness.

questions.question: Efua was not in the good book of teachers at Forcados High School because

options.text: her admission into the senior class was unusual
she was expelled from her previous school
the students of the school did not like her
she bribed the principal before she was admitted

questions.explanation: Teachers are prejudiced against Efua because of her **expulsion from a previous school**, which gives her a bad reputation before she even starts at Forcados. Her admission procedure (A) and student popularity (C) are secondary; bribery (D) is never mentioned.

questions.question: These questions are based on A. H. Mohammed's "The First Days at Forcados High School".
questions.explanation: This "question" simply indicates which question number begins the Forcados High School section. That is Question 21, so option A is correct.

questions.question: Ramatu expressed her feelings in no uncertain terms.

options.text: She expressed them feebly and sickly.
She expressed them quietly and cautiously.
She expressed them secretly and courageously.
She expressed them clearly and strongly.

questions.explanation: To speak "in no uncertain terms" is to be **very clear and direct**, leaving no doubt about what you mean. That matches D. The other options suggest weakness, caution or secrecy, which are opposite to the idiom’s emphasis.

questions.question: Usman needs to get his act together if he wants to pass the examination.

options.text: He needs to put on his stage costume.
He needs to be fast when writing the examination.
He needs to put all points down in the examination.

questions.explanation: "Get his act together" means to **organise himself** and start behaving efficiently and responsibly. It has nothing to do with costumes or speed of writing.

questions.question: As the drama unfolded, Olatinuke was advised to keep her shirt on.

options.text: She was advised to stay calm.
She was advised to commit herself.
She was advised to join the club.
She was advised to wear her shirt.

questions.explanation: The informal idiom "keep your shirt on" means "calm down" or "don't get so angry". It is not about literally wearing or removing clothing.

questions.question: The team's poor performance at the tournament plunged the depths of horror.

options.text: The team's performance took them to the next round.
The team's performance was enjoyed by all.
The team's performance was full of disappointment.

questions.explanation: The hyperbolic phrase "plunged the depths of horror" suggests something extremely bad or disappointing. So the team's performance was **very poor**, full of disappointment. The other options are positive and contradict the writer's tone.

questions.question: He is a clinging child.

options.text: He likes to cling with his sister.
He is a handsome young man.

questions.explanation: A "clinging" child is one who hangs on to parents or carers and does not like to be apart—overly dependent and **possessive**. The word does not imply bullying or physical attractiveness.

questions.question: You need to brush up on your Spanish.

options.text: You need a brush from Spain.
You need to study the history of Spain.
You need to learn to play with a Spaniard.
You need to improve your skills.

questions.explanation: "Brush up on" a subject means to review and **improve your skills or knowledge** in it. The phrase has nothing to do with physical brushes or playing with Spaniards.

questions.question: Tolu and Chinedu live in each other's pockets.

options.text: They are very close to each other.

questions.explanation: To "live in each other's pockets" means to spend a great deal of time together, often inseparably. That indicates they are **very close friends**, not enemies, and the expression is not literal.

questions.question: Zinana's examination result was not unfavourable.

options.text: Her result could not earn her admission.
She was successful in the examination.
She was not successful in the examination.

questions.explanation: The double negative "not unfavourable" means essentially "favourable"—the result was good. Therefore Zinana **succeeded** in the exam (C). Options A, B, and D all suggest poor performance.

questions.question: "I can't wait to become a mother," the new bride declared.

options.text: She sees motherhood as a burden.
She will be patient as a mother.
She is not keen on becoming a mother.

questions.explanation: The phrase "I can't wait" expresses eagerness and **excitement**. The bride looks forward to motherhood; she does not see it as a burden (A) and certainly is not indifferent (C).

questions.question: The relationship between the couple has been frosty.
questions.explanation: "Frosty" here means cold and unfriendly. The clear opposite is "cordial"—warm and friendly. 'Amenable' means willing to agree, 'frugal' refers to careful spending, and 'fraudulent' means deceitful; none are true antonyms.

questions.question: The dressmaker unpicked the seam of the shirt.
questions.explanation: To "unpick" a seam is to remove the stitches. The exact opposite is to "sew up"—to stitch the seam closed again. 'Tore up' and 'picked up' relate to different actions; 'threaded' means putting thread into a needle or through a hole.

questions.question: Some of my neighbours have an antipathy to dogs.
questions.explanation: "Antipathy" is a strong feeling of dislike or aversion. The opposite feeling is **affection**—a liking or fondness. 'Enmity' is similar to antipathy, not opposite. 'Alarm for' and 'acronym' are unrelated.

questions.question: Chibuzor gave a curt nod and walked away.
questions.explanation: "Curt" describes something brief to the point of seeming rude. Its opposite in manner is "polite"—courteous and considerate. 'Rude' is a synonym, not an antonym, and 'gentle' and 'shocking' do not form a clear semantic opposite.

questions.question: The girl took a cursory glance at the letter and hid it.
questions.explanation: "Cursory" means quick and superficial—done rapidly without careful attention. Among the options, the best opposite is "lasting" (C), which suggests something that endures, i.e. is not momentary or rushed. 'Brief' is actually close in meaning to 'cursory'; 'sententious' means moralising, and 'concise' means expressed in few words, not opposite to 'cursory' in this context.

questions.question: The accused was eventually convicted.
questions.explanation: "Eventually" means "after a long time or delay". The opposite temporal point is "initially"—at the beginning. The other adverbs (finally, subsequently, consequently) also refer to later stages, not the start.

questions.question: My niece has an unquenchable thirst for adventure stories.
questions.explanation: "Unquenchable" means a desire that cannot be satisfied or put out—very strong and continuing. Among the given options, the closest opposite idea is "reduced" (D), suggesting a weaker, diminished thirst. Options A and B focus on *legitimacy*, not strength, and C is a synonym.

questions.question: Musa is a gifted but erratic player.
questions.explanation: "Erratic" means inconsistent and unpredictable. The opposite is "regular"—steady and consistent. 'Unstable' and 'unpredictable' are synonyms of erratic, not antonyms; 'strong' is about power, not consistency.

questions.question: The testimony of the witness was vague.
questions.explanation: "Vague" testimony is unclear or lacking in detail. The precise opposite is "clear". 'Real', 'factual', and 'true' concern truth, not clarity; a statement can be true yet still vague.

questions.question: As a student, Isa tried communal living for a few years.
questions.explanation: "Communal" means shared by a community or group. Its antonym is "private", meaning belonging to one person or closed to others. 'Shared' and 'collective' are synonyms, and 'general' is too vague.

questions.question: The lamb is a feeble little animal.
questions.explanation: "Feeble" means weak or lacking strength. None of the options is a perfect lexical antonym (like "strong" would be), but 'weak' (B) is actually a synonym. Among the remaining choices, 'fat' suggests a sturdier, more substantial animal and is therefore the least similar to "feeble" in the context of physical condition, which is why it is taken as the opposite here.

questions.question: The exhibition was an eye opener to all.
questions.explanation: An "exhibition" is a **display** of items (art, products, etc.) for the public. 'Dispatch' means to send off; 'examination' means a test; 'style' is a way of doing something.

questions.question: The first round of the tournament was a doddle.
questions.explanation: "A doddle" is British slang for something very **easy**. None of the other options share that meaning: 'exasperating' means frustrating, 'balanced' means evenly matched, and 'dodgy' means risky or unreliable.

questions.question: As a journalist, Bala has always had a nose for stories.
questions.explanation: To "have a nose for" something is to have a natural **instinct** or talent for finding it. The phrase is common in journalism. 'A command', 'cynical statement', and 'soft comment' do not convey this idea of intuitive ability.

questions.question: The actress screamed when she noticed an object behind her.
questions.explanation: To "scream" is to **shout** loudly, especially in fear. 'Wailed' implies crying in grief, 'protested' means objected, and 'cried' is ambiguous between weeping and calling out.

questions.question: Today's weather is favourable for a game of tennis.
questions.explanation: "Favourable" conditions help or encourage an activity. 'Encouraging' thus comes closest in meaning. 'Impartial' is about fairness; 'abnormal' about deviation from normal; 'disapproving' expresses negative judgement.

questions.question: All the candidates looked aghast at the first reading of the questions.
questions.explanation: "Aghast" means horrified or extremely shocked. 'Dismayed'—deeply disappointed or distressed—best matches this reaction. 'Fulfilled' and 'satisfied' suggest pleased feelings, the opposite of aghast; 'again' is not an emotion.

questions.question: I am tired of your eternal argument.
questions.explanation: Here "eternal" means seemingly endless or **constant**. The speaker is frustrated that the argument never stops. The other options (open, strong, useless) comment on other aspects of an argument but not its continuity.

questions.question: Joke gave Muhammad a jaunty smile.
questions.explanation: "Jaunty" means lively, confident, and **cheerful**. Option B expresses this mood best. 'Inviting' may overlap in friendliness but does not capture the lively spirit; A and C are negative in tone.

questions.question: You live in the city now, ___ ?
questions.explanation: For a present simple statement with "you live", the correct question tag is "don't you?" (auxiliary 'do' + not + subject). 'Are you?' would tag a sentence with 'you are'; 'didn't you?' refers to past; 'haven't you?' to present perfect.

questions.question: Concrete is made of ___
questions.explanation: In this generic statement, 'sand' and 'cement' are uncountable mass nouns, so no articles are needed. "Concrete is made of **sand and cement**" is the normal expression. The other options use incorrect articles or word order.

questions.question: Suana ___ that hexagons had five sides, but later he knew they were six‑sided figures.
questions.explanation: There are two past‑time points: first, the mistaken belief; later, the corrected knowledge. The earlier past action should be in the past perfect: "Suana **had believed** ... but later he knew...". This shows the belief came before the knowing.

questions.question: The ___ to the fallen heroes was erected at the market square.
questions.explanation: A structure built to honour fallen heroes is a **monument**. Exhibitions and pictures are displays, not necessarily permanent memorials; 'myth' is a traditional story.

questions.question: The Flying Eagles of Nigeria couldn't have won the match if they hadn't prepared well, ___?
questions.explanation: The main clause is a negative conditional: "couldn't have won". The tag question should use the opposite polarity and the same modal: "**could they?**". 'Couldn't they?' repeats the negative; 'can they?' and 'can't they?' change the tense.

questions.question: They all gathered to exhume the ___ musician's corpse for examination.
questions.explanation: The examination done on a dead body is a **post‑mortem examination**. 'Posthumous' usually describes awards or publications after a person's death; 'post‑natal' refers to after birth; 'orthopaedic' relates to bones and joints.

questions.question: I have been doing this exercise ___
questions.explanation: The present perfect continuous ("have been doing") takes "for + length of time": "for five minutes". 'Five minutes ago' goes with the simple past; 'since five minutes' is incorrect; 'during five minutes' is unnatural here.

questions.question: Oloyede always sleeps like a baby, ___?
questions.explanation: The main clause is present simple affirmative: "Oloyede always sleeps..." The correct negative tag is "doesn't he?". 'Does he?' would expect agreement with a negative statement; 'could he?' and 'did he?' use wrong auxiliaries or tenses.

questions.question: The man was given a degree despite the fact that he did not attend a ___ university.
questions.explanation: People who have not studied for a degree but receive one in recognition of achievement are awarded an **honorary degree**. 'Honourable' is used of people or actions; 'ceremonial' and 'ceremonious' relate to formality, not degree type.

questions.question: My father has just bought ___
questions.explanation: The correct English order is: determiner + adjectives + noun. "A brand new Peugeot" uses 'brand new' (adjective phrase) before the make of the car (Peugeot). The other options misorder the words.

questions.question: The university is a corporate body made ___ different colleges.
questions.explanation: The correct expression is "made **up of**", meaning composed of: "made up of different colleges". The other combinations are not idiomatic.

questions.question: The secretary hadn't ___ money left.
questions.explanation: With a negative verb and an uncountable noun ('money'), we use "any": "hadn't any money left". 'Anything' would need a verb ('hadn't anything to spend'), and 'no'/'none' would cause a double negative ('hadn't no').

questions.question: The King was recognised ___ the scar on his face.
questions.explanation: We say someone is "recognised **by**" a particular feature. The scar is the means of identification. 'With' is used for accompanying things; 'to' and 'for' are wrong here.

questions.question: Nkiru has lots of friends, but I have ___
questions.explanation: With a plural countable noun like 'friends', we use 'few' or 'a few', not 'little'. The contrast with 'lots of friends' is best expressed as "only a few" friends—small in number but some. 'Few' alone is also possible but 'only a few' gives the emphasis signalled by 'but'.

questions.question: The HOD says she considers her degree certificate ___ than as a prize through labour.

options.text: rather as a gift of God
as a gift rather of God
as a rather gift of God

questions.explanation: The correct comparative construction is "rather ... than ...": she considers it **rather as a gift of God** than as a prize she laboured for. The other options misuse 'rather' or scramble the word order.

questions.question: Mr Ojo instructed his son to replace the faulty ___ tube.
questions.explanation: The correct spelling is "fluorescent" tube (a type of light). 'Florescent' and 'flourescent' are misspellings; 'fluence' is a different word.

questions.question: The employer, not the salesmen, ___ responsible for the loss.
questions.explanation: The true subject is "The employer", which is singular, so the verb must be singular: "was". The phrase "not the salesmen" is a parenthetical contrast and does not affect agreement. 'Have been' and 'were' are plural; 'will be' changes the tense to future.

questions.question: She was ___ as anyone could have had.
questions.explanation: The idiom is "as [adjective] as [noun]": "She was **as patient as teacher**" (i.e. as patient as any teacher could be). The other options either misuse articles or omit 'as'.

questions.question: There was a serious ___ between the new couple over feeding allowance.
questions.explanation: "Argument" is the correct spelling. 'Arguement' is an incorrect variant. Since A and D are both 'argument', either could be seen as correct textually, but standard keying uses the first correct option.

questions.question: They thought Musa ___ agree if they altered some of the conditions.
questions.explanation: In reported thought about a **past** possibility, 'might' is usual: "They thought Musa might agree...". 'Can' and 'may' are present‑time; 'could' suggests ability or a more definite possibility but 'might' aligns best with tentative expectation.

questions.question: For these questions, choose the option that has the same sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
questions.explanation: This item simply introduces the phonetics section starting at Question 86. The first word to consider is **Waiter** (Q86), so A points to the correct next example.

questions.question: Waiter
questions.explanation: In *waiter*, the underlined "ai" is pronounced /eɪ/ (WAI‑ter). *Flavour* /ˈfleɪvə/ also contains /eɪ/. *Cite* has /aɪ/, *road* has /əʊ/, and *hair* has /eə/. Phonetics questions focus on sound, not spelling.

questions.question: Flee
questions.explanation: *Flee* and *field* both contain the long vowel /iː/ (fliː, fiːld). *Skate* and *faith* have /eɪ/, and *rid* has /ɪ/.

questions.question: Palm
questions.explanation: In many accents (especially British English), *palm* is pronounced /pɑːm/. *Ranch* is /rɑːntʃ/, sharing the /ɑː/ vowel. *Florid* has /ɒ/ or /ɔː/; *blunt* and *lunch* have /ʌ/.

questions.question: Phantom
questions.explanation: In *phantom*, the underlined "ph" represents the consonant /f/. The same spelling‑sound relationship appears in *physics* (/ˈfɪzɪks/). In *pew* and *phew*, the underlined letters represent /pj/ or /fj/; in *party*, the /p/ sound is written with 'p', not 'ph'.

questions.question: Chest
questions.explanation: In the exam, the **letter(s) underlined** in *chest* are the 's', representing the consonant /s/. The same /s/ sound, written 'ss', occurs in *mass* /mæs/. In *fixture*, the 'x' is /ks/; in *school*, 'sch' is /sk/; in *charisma*, 'ch' is /k/. Only *mass* matches the /s/ sound.

questions.question: Epitaph
questions.explanation: In *epitaph*, the underlined letters 'ph' represent /f/ at the end of the word. The same /f/ sound, written 'f', appears at the start of *fan* /fæn/. In *pneumonia* the 'p' is silent; 'paper' begins with /p/; 'pseudo' has 'ps' pronounced /s/.

questions.question: Ever
questions.explanation: *Ever* and *never* both end with /evə/. *Fever* has /iːvə/, and *heavier* and *favour* have /eɪvə/ in many accents, so they are only near‑rhymes.

questions.question: Cable
questions.explanation: *Cable* /ˈkeɪbəl/ rhymes with *able* /ˈeɪbəl/—both have the /eɪbəl/ ending. *Bible* has /aɪbəl/, and *marble* has /ɑːbəl/. 'Mabel' (proper noun) also has /eɪbəl/ but exams typically choose a common word like 'able'.

questions.question: Mail
questions.explanation: *Mail* /meɪl/ and *bale* /beɪl/ both end in /eɪl/. *Slate* ends in /eɪt/, *girl* in /ɜːl/, and *galle* (if pronounced /gæl/) does not rhyme.

questions.question: Advantages
questions.explanation: *Advantages* has three syllables: ad‑VAN‑tages (/ədˈvɑːntɪdʒɪz/). The main stress is on the second syllable 'VAN', which option B correctly shows. The other options stress the wrong syllable.

questions.question: Intentional
questions.explanation: *Intentional* has four syllables: in‑TEN‑tion‑al (/ɪnˈtenʃənəl/). The stress is on 'TEN', the second syllable. Option A marks this correctly.

questions.question: For this question, choose the option that is stressed on the first syllable.
questions.explanation: *Guilty* is pronounced GUIL‑ty, with stress on the first syllable. *Guitar* is gui‑TAR, *confuse* is con‑FUSE, and *relief* is re‑LIEF—all stressed on the second syllable. So only option B meets the requirement.

questions.question: I left my bag on the TABLE.

options.text: Did you leave your bag on the desk?
Did you leave your bag under the table?
Did you leave the shoe on the table?
Who left the bag on the table?

questions.explanation: The capitalised word TABLE is being **emphasised**, so the question it answers must have something **else** in that position that needs correction. Question B—"Did you leave your bag **under** the table?"—implies the wrong location. The emphatic reply "No, I left my bag on the **TABLE**" corrects 'under' to 'on'. The other questions focus on the object or the person, not the place, so stressing TABLE would not directly answer them.

questions.question: Kanu can play FOOTBALL.

options.text: What can Kanu do with football?

questions.explanation: With emphasis on **FOOTBALL**, the sentence is really answering a "what" question about the activity: "What can Kanu play?" (B). The answer, "Kanu can play **FOOTBALL**", corrects or specifies the item. Questions A, C and D ask about the person, an action, or a reason, not about which game he can play.

questions.question: Aisha plays TENNIS always.
questions.explanation: Here the stressed word is **TENNIS**. The natural question is "What does Aisha play always?" (C). The reply "Aisha plays **TENNIS** always" correctly emphasises the kind of game. A asks about the person, B changes 'plays' to 'watch', and D asks about time rather than the sport.
